There's this bit in Mathematics in Lean:

The left and right versions are easily shown to be equivalent, given the commutativity of ⊓ and ⊔. It is a good exercise to show that not every lattice is distributive by providing an explicit description of a nondistributive lattice with finitely many elements. It is also a good exercise to show that in any lattice, either distributivity law implies the other

Regarding the part I bolded — I just want to confirm that this isn't something we can actually do with the material explained in the book so far, is it? I expect we'd need to define a type of a specific shape and somehow posit it is a Lattice. I'm sure it's doable but am I correct that this isn't something that was actually covered in the book so far, and so isn't really expected to be solved?

cc @Jeremy Avigad

I think that part is only meant to be done informally (if at all). To formalize that in Lean, you'd indeed need to construct an instance of a lattice, and constructing instances of structures is explained in chapter 6.
Dan Abramov has marked this topic as resolved.
